monogr.title: The mynde of the godly and excellent lerned man M. Ihon Caluyne : what a faithfull man, whiche is instructe in the worde of God, ought to do, dwellinge amongest the papistes
monogr.author: Calvin, Jean

div.head: The Preface to the Reader.
div.p:
SEnce yt Sathan was losed oute of the botomles pyt,Apoc. 20. and (for mans vnthankfulnes towarde God for his manifolde benefytes) permytted to range through out the whole worlde, to deceyue mankynde, man off hym selfe naturally prone vnto euyll, & therfore readie to enclyne to his diabolycall suggestions and temptations / wel nygh all ye whole worlde (a fewe of the lytle flocke of Christ onely excepte,Gene. viij whō it hathe pleased God of his mercie so to preserue, as he alwayes doth his church that they haue not bowed their knees to Baal) hath neglected and set naught by Goddes euerlastynge testament & gospell which is the power of god in to saluation 3. Reg. 19. Rom. 1.
to all them yt beleue. And wheare as they knewe there was a god, & haue not worshipped him as god, nor thanked hym, but became vayne in their ymaginations, and theyr foolyshe herte was blynded, when they counted them selues wyse, they became fooles: and turned the glorie of the incorruptible God into the symylitude of a corruptible mā &c. Wherfore God, likewise, gaue them vp vnto their hertes lustes into vncleannes, to defyle their owne bodies in them selues, which turned the truthe of god in to a lie, so that they worshipped & serued the creature more then ye creator, which is blessed for euer and euer.

Rom. 1And what more ensued Sainct Paul declareth, They Iustlie receyued the rewarde of their erroure, and as they had no regarde to knowe God, euen so god gaue them vp vnto a lewde mynd, to do those thynges whiche were not comelie beyng full of all vnrightuousnes whoredome, wickednes, couetousnes, malyciousnes, full of enuye, murther, stryfe, deceite, euell cōdicioned, whisperers, backe biters, dispisers of god, doers of wronge
proude, boasters, bringers vp of euyll thinges, disobedyent to their elders, wt oute vnderstanding, couenaūt breakers, vnlouing, stubburne, vnmercifull, & endued with all kynde of wyckednes.

Thus doest yu see (good Christian reader) howe daungerous a thynge it is, to neglect or dispyse the myghtie worde of god, against whiche (notwithstanding) the gates of hell can not preuayle: so yt in dispisynge or resystinge it althoughe of a malycious or peruerse mynde, thou goest aboute to suppresse & kepe it backe thou dost nothing els but procure thine owne dampnation, the worde of god florisshinge neuertheles: for as the gospell is saluation, to them that beleue it, so is it dampnatiō to them that beleue it not. This dothe Christe verifie and affirme him selfe, saying,Ihon. 12. he that refuseth me and receyueth not my wordes, hath one all ready that iudgeth hym.
The worde whiche I haue spoken, yt shall iudge hym at the latter daye: for he shall haue nothynge to cloke his synne wythall.Ihon. 15.

Paraduenture we wyll thynke that
Saynct Paul doth speake those thinges onelye of those yt were before his dayes and so perswade our selues that it was nothinge meant of vs, but in lesse then we cā proue our selues not giltie in those and lyke offences that they in the olde lawe were plaged and punisshed for, let vs not perswade our selues to be cleare of lyke threatenynges. No, let vs loke for none other thinge, but to be caste vp of god into a reprobate and leude mynd and so headlonge into all fylthynes and iniquitie the iuste rewarde of our errour whose ende is death euerlastynge.

Deut. viij.God fed ye Israelytes with fyne Māna sente them from aboue, they abhorred it & wisshed to be at their full grosse fleash pottes agayne in Egipte.Exo. 16. They were plaged for their vnthankefulnes. God hath sente vs the true Manna,Ioh. vi his euerlastynge word ye bread of lyfe we abhor it, we can not abyde it, we wolde be at ye full pottes of ye grosse flesshe of mennes traditions to poyson our selues. Well, shall we thinke to escape gods wrathe? Is god become a chaungelyng? will he not punysshe vs, for our vnthankefulnes
as he dyd them? yea trulie. For we be more worthy of punishment then they, seing we haue their punishmēt,Num. xi. for an ensample before our eyes to beware by.

God also brought the children of Israel out of Egipt by wonderfull miracle,Exod. 14. for when it was vnpossible by all reason, but ye other they shoulde haue bene destroyed by Pharao and his armye being behynde them: or else to haue bene all drowned in the rede sea before them: the mightie power of god caused the deepe sea to stande on eyther syde of them like a wall so that they passed through it safe lie, but theyr enemyes pursuinge them were drowned horse and man. Wheare as they ought with whole herte & mind continually duringe their lyues to haue geuen thankes vnto that myghtie god alone for their deliueraunce: they shortly after made them a goldē calfe,Exo. 32 fell down and worshiped it, offering sacrifyce vnto it, saying. These be thy goddes (O Israell) whiche haue brought the out of the lande of Egypte. This their vnthankful Idolatry Moyses called ye greatest sinne and was greuously punysshed: for there
ensued murder of ye Israelites to ye nombre of xxiij.m. Now if it can be proued, yt we haue shewd no such vnthākfulnes toward god, haue not resisted his word nor cōmitted no such lyke offence: then may we sleape the more careles and feare no suche plages to fall vpon vs, for of thys we may be sure, God will not punysshe vs without a cause. But amongest many other thinges, what say you to thys, I pray you? We were longe in Egypte that is in the bondage and captiuitie of Pharao the deuyll, and when we could be delyuered by no power no merite or intercession of any creature besyde christ visyble or inuisible / mortal or immortall / & wher as it was impossible to al reason, but other we shoulde be euerlastinglye drowned in ye red fiery sea of hell & death being allwaies before our eyes: or els to be deuoured of the furiouse Pharao the deuyll pursuinge vs: God of his mere mercye (aboue all our desert) sente hys onely begotten sonne Christe Iesus, to become verie man and dye for vs, for in as moch as we had committed suche offenceGen. 2. as was forbidden in paine of deth
we muste nedes be redeamed agayn by death, and that by suche a one yt shoulde not remayne dead styll, for then shoulde not he ouercome death but death ouercome hym: therfore muste he ryse again and so by death ouercome death.

This parte hath christ played alone. He died for our redemption,1. Cor. 15. 1. Cor. 1 Ephe. 1 he rose againe for our iustification & so ouercame death synne and hell: and thus moste wonderfully delyuered vs out of euerlastynge thraldom and captiuite. But haue we alwayes ascribed the renowne and glorie of our redemption and forgeuenesse of synnes to god alone? No no but rather to masses satysfactorie with sondry other vayne traditions of man. To whō do we attribute, or whom do we prayse for our daylie preseruation from perilles and Ieoperdyes? God alone? No, our manyfeste actes do openly reproue vs. How many men and womē haue bene, when they haue bene in daunger / some of drowninge, some of burninge, some of • reakynge their neckes, and some lyeng so sycke that to all reason they semed vn
••… rable, that, yf god of his goodnes preserued
them and raysed them vp agayn, wold shortly after get them to one ydol or other (to whom thei had vowed their pilgrimage and offeringe) as some to ye ladie of Walsyngham some to the ladye of Grace, or vnto some other foule ydoll. And where as they shoulde haue geuen glorie and praise to the one euerlastyng god, which alone delyuered thē they haue kneeled downe in the sight of the whole multitude & thanked a dome ymage, worshippyng and offering their ydolatrous sacrifice vnto it. Was not this ydolatry worse thē the worshipping of the golden calfe? yes trulie. For then sacrifice was commaunded to be offered to god with calues, but not calues to be worshipped: as for ydolatrous ymages were forbydden then as they be nowe. And for that the people might be yt more allured to lyke abhomynation ye priestes taught them for their owne aduauntage to come onely in their shirtes & smockes what was this els but to say with ye Israelytes? These be thi goddes (o Israel) whiche haue brought the out of ye lande of Egipte & bondage: yea and no doubt
the worlde bothe hath and shall be plaged wt as greuous plages as they were, yf it do not earnestly repent and forsake not onely suche abhomination: but also all kynde of ydolatrie that is, all inward or outwarde worshipping of the ymage of any thinge visyble or invisyble: or sea kyng forgeuenes of synnes or saluation at any creature mortall or immortal, but only at gods mercy, & yt for christes sake.

More ouer for these and suche lyke our vnthankefulnes and offences, God had iustly geuen vs vp into such a lewde and reprobate mynde, that all we (a few excepte) were not onely geuen headlong into all kynde of vyce and ydolatrie: but were so ferre gone yt we were iuste partakers of the curse pronounced out off goddes mouthe by the prophete Esaie.Esai. 5 wo be to you yt call euyl good, and good euyll, makyng derkenes lyght and light derkenes, takynge bitternes for swetnes and swetnes for bytternes. In this case were we. That whiche was vyce and abhomination, we toke for godlynes and vertue: And that whiche was godlynes and vertue in dede, we toke for heresie &
synne: for who was he yt thought it not godly to professe him self into an abbey frier house or nonry? Who was he that spake against them, and that with gods worde but he shoulde be hated and persecuted? Who was he that thought but that it was hyghlie meritorious to go on pylgrimage to this or that ymage? Who was he that coulde speake against them but he should be in daunger of his life? Who durst speake against ye Popes hote purgatorie, but that he shoulde be burned to asshes? And as for the abusing of the lordes supper whiche they called the sacrament of the Aultare, he yt spake but a worde against it, or againste their wycked masses satisfactorie (thoughe it were the verie scripture) hangynge was to good for hym, he must dye most cruel death. But thankes be to ye eternall god for he (to the declaration of his glorie & for his electes sake) hath styrred vp men as his instrumentes to speake, write and printe myghtelie against suche abhomination, and he hathe turned the hartes and powers of some christen Princes against them to suppresse them and roote
out all suche plantes as our heauenly father hath not planted.

❧ Finally, seing that papisticall abhomynations and ydolatries be now well nyghe all knowen though they be yet scarcely halfe lefte in many places, it is requisite and highly necessarie to know how a faithfull christian man, endued wt the spirite of god & truely taught in hys worde, shall behaue hymselfe amonge ye papistes, were in and how ferre he may be conuersaunt with them: namely, whether he may be present at their masse and supersticious Ceremonies wtout offence in yt he, although by owtwarde gestures as by cappynge and kneelynge seme to worshippe with them, doth notwithstādynge in his herte worshippe the onely lyuynge god: whether he may lawfully vse suche dissimulation or not? For thy full erudition & learnyng in this behalfe although veri few writers haue touched this poincte (namely in the Englysshe tongue) here haste thou (good Christiā) this notable work of M. Ihon Caluyn a man of good learnynge and godlie cōuersation, now firste translated into Englysshe:
which, if thou, dilygentlie reade peruse and marke with sobernes, it wylfullie satisfy thy mynde in this behalfe wher as certen places in scripture (afte • some mennes myndes) seme to beare wt such dissymulation in worshipping thou shalte haue them moste manyfestly opened vnto the: so that thou shalt perfectly knowe, that all that be of Christ oughte not onely to confesse God with ye harte inwardly, but also (after the councell of Saincte Paule) to confesse the lyuinge god with the mouthe and gloryfie hym in their bodyes professynge him in all their outwarde gesture and behauiour.Rom. 10. 1. Cor. 6.
